description: Shocking video showing three 'zombie women' who appear to be on drugs on the street in broad daylight has emerged, with the trio seen stumbling around in circles and barely able to stand.
title: Video shows three 'zombie women on drugs'
title_page: Video shows three 'zombie women on drugs' | Daily Mail Online
text:
Shocking video showing three 'zombie women' who appear to be on drugs on the street in broad daylight has emerged.
The trio are seen staggering around in circles near a bus stop in the short clip, with two of the women appearing to be holding cigarettes in their hand.
Many people walk passed throughout the clip, with some laughing at the shocking scene.
Shocking video showing three 'zombie women' who appear to be on drugs on the street in broad daylight has emerged
The trio were noticeably struggling to stand and appeared to be under the influence of drugs
Two of the women appeared to be holding cigarettes of some form during the short video
The video last for about two minutes, with the three women visibly struggling throughout it.
One of the trio is seen leaning against the bus stop, another looks like she was walked into a wall, and a third stumbles back and forth at almost ninety degrees while carrying a plastic bag.
It is not clear where the video was shot, however some comments claim the incident was filmed in Baltimore.
And while it is not known if the women in the video were on drugs, the way they struggle to stand and walk is similar to how a group of people in Brooklyn were impacted after using synthetic marijuana last year.
Many people walk passed throughout the clip, with some laughing at the shocking scene
This woman with a cane stopped to look as she walked passed. When she was further away, both her and the woman she was with turned to look back again at the 'zombies'
It is not known if the women in the new video were on drugs, but their behavior appeared similar to 'K-2 zombies' who were seen in Brooklyn last year
WHAT IS SYNTHETIC MARIJUANA? Synthetic marijuana contains man-made chemicals that act on the same cell receptors in the brain as THC does in natural marijuana. Researchers have found instances in which chemicals in synthetic marijuana can bind much more strongly to cell receptors than THC does in marijuana that is grown. This can produce stronger effects, such as an elevated mood or feeling of relaxation. But synthetic marijuana is also known to have psychotic effects on some users. These can include extreme anxiety, confusion, paranoia and even hallucinations. (Source: National Institute of Drug Abuse)
A total of 33 people staggered around a street corner in Brooklyn's Bedford-Stuyvestant and Bushwick neighborhoods after taking a drug called K-2 last July.
Shocking pictures of the 'K-2 zombies' were taken, with those under the influence of the drug were barely able to stand.
The drug was later identified as Amb-fubinaca, which is 85 times more potent than the main agent in plant-grown marijuana, TCH.
Amb-fubinaca was originally developed by pharmaceutical giant Pfizer, which established a patent for it back in 2009.
Amb-fubinaca is made in powdered form which is then mixed with herbal products and smoked.
It is often sold for as little as $1 per hit.
Experts have been concerned about the growing danger of the synthetic drug market, due to a combination of its high availability, cheap selling price, and massive potential potency.
A man is seen in Brooklyn last year staggering and being held up by paramedics after overdosing on synthetic marijuana
